briefTitle: Objective EEG Bed Side Assessment of Impaired Conscious Awareness in Epilepsy
officialTitle: Objective EEG Bed Side Assessment of Impaired Conscious Awareness in Epilepsy

eligibilityCriteria.criteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* age minimum 18 years
* diagnosis of (absence) epilepsy // healthy age-matched controls
* being of good health (besides epilepsy in the case group)

Exclusion Criteria:

* central nervous system disorders (besides epilepsy in the case group)
* substance abuse
* pregnancy

primary.measure: temporal integration changes according to different sleep states
primary.description: The investigators develop an EEG-based measure of impaired conscious awareness based on wakefulness and deepening sleep stages which will serve as a model for increasingly impaired conscious awareness. By performing a microstate analysis on EEG data, the investigators hypothesize a decrease of the temporal integration, a prerequisite for conscious awareness, of the EEG gradually from wakefulness to deep sleep.

primary.measure: temporal integration changes in interictal EEG
primary.description: The investigators apply the aforementioned analysis (leading to Outcome 1) on interictal EEG recordings obtained from patients with diagnosed absence epilepsy. The investigators hypothesize a reduced temporal integration in epilepsies with reduced consciousness.

primary.measure: graph modularity changes according to different sleep states
primary.description: The investigators will calculate the EEG-based functional connectivity and graph modularity for each sleep state. The investigators hypothesize that during wakefulness, graph modularity will be lower than during the descent to sleep.

primary.measure: graph modularity changes in interictal EEG
primary.description: The investigators will calculate the EEG-based functional connectivity and graph modularity for the absence epilepsy condition. The investigators hypothesize that impaired consciousness will be reflected in lower graph modularity compared to healthy subjects.

secondary.description: The investigators hypothesize that the graph modularity level correlates with neuropsychological test scores in the surveyed data of epilepsy patients.
